description: Perhaps a blend of chuckle +â€Ž snort. Coined by Lewis Carroll in his poem Jabberwocky, first published in 1855 but only introduced to the public in his 1871 novel Through the Looking-Glass.

entries.meaning: A joyful, somewhat muffled laugh, rather like a snorting chuckle.
examples: He frequently interrupted himself with chortles while he told us his favorite joke.

entries.meaning: A similar sounding vocalisation of various birds.

verbs.description: chortle (third-person singular simple present chortles, present participle chortling, simple past and past participle chortled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To laugh with a chortle or chortles.
examples: The old fellow chortled as he recalled his youthful adventures.
